Award.AwardTitle: Carrier Dynamics in Quantum Dot Solar Cells and Infrared Detectors

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract:

Abstract Title: "Understanding the enhancement mechanisms of optical energy conversion efficiency in solar cells based on confinement by quantum dots"

Nontechnical:
Photovoltaic is a technology that permits the conversion of abundant radiative energy from the sun to electrical energy which can ultimately be widely distributed using a smart electrical grid infrastructure. This can be done with a minimum negative impact on the environment. In spite of being a well-established clean source of energy, there is a need for improving the present conversion efficiency of Si solar cells. New materials and new approaches to achieve this goal have emerged. One appealing approach is based on using different materials with different bandgap to enhance the conversion efficiency of present solar cells. Another approach is based on using confined nanostructures, called quantum dots, to convert solar energy with high efficiency. This latter approach has the advantage of being simpler and does not require complex growth processes. This might be a very inexpensive approach to making solar cells. On the other hand, this approach has not yet demonstrated its potential. Different experimental studies are proposed with the goal of understanding the potential and limitations of this approach. The proposed approach involves an effort toward a better understanding of light absorption in these structures in order to design very efficient solar cells based on quantum dots. If successful, this project will have a major impact on clean and efficient energy conversion in this country.

Technical:
Photovoltaic devices based on p-n junction are the most mature technology for solar-energy harvesting. This proposal seeks to develop new highly efficient GaAs quantum dot solar cells based on the intermediate band concept. These cells have the potential of being as efficient as 3-junction solar cells but at a much lower level of complexity. The concept of intermediate band solar cells has been with us for more than 15 years. Unfortunately, these solar cells have so far demonstrated a limited conversion efficiency of 18 % or less. This is in large part related to the fact that researchers have not been able to demonstrate an intermediate band solar cell with a well-defined intermediate band Fermi energy, detached from the conduction band Fermi energy. Some key measurements on intermediate band solar cells that have not been attempted before are proposed in order to shed light on this topic. In particular, two-photon measurements using two optical sources of different wavelengths are proposed to understand if a 2-photon absorption can be measured and if the process is based on sequential photons absorption or due to simultaneous two-photon absorption. This will answer the question if intermediate band solar cells can be realized with well-defined intermediate band Fermi energy, detached from the conduction band Fermi energy. If substantially higher efficiencies cannot be reached using the concept of intermediate band solar cells, implying that the concept is basically flawed, this needs to be investigated and a final answer has to be provided with a clear explanation. Additionally, since the physics of these solar cells is similar to the physics describing photon absorption in IR-detectors, this new understanding will also lead to a better understanding of the operation of quantum dot infrared photodetectors (QDIPs). Two quantum dot solar cells will be studied with different bandgaps to optimize the predicted conversion efficiency of intermediate band solar cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The efficiency of conversion of solar energy to useful electrical power is decribed by a parameter called the power conversion efficiency. The goal of research on solar cells is to enhance this conversion efficiency. The record conversion efficiency of single junction solar cells is about 29.1%. and uses GaAs. The record conversion efficiency of multi-junction concentrator solar cells is above 47%. In this case, the incident light is concentrated on the solar cell. On the other hand, more than 95% of all shipments by U.S. manufacturers to the residential sector are based on crystalline solar panels. About 20 years ago, it was predicted by Luque and Marti that by using the concept of an intermediate band, it would be possible to sizably increase the power conversion efficiency of single junction solar cells to the solar conversion efficiency more typical of 3-junction solar cells. According to this concept, beyond the photocurrent being generated by direct band-to-band transitions, there would be an additional path that would use two photons,  a lower and a higher energy photon to create additional photocurrent that would enhance the overall conversion efficiency of a single junction solar cell. Unfotunately, over tha last 20 years, there has been a large amount of work in this area but the work has not produced any solar cell with higher conversion efficiency as compared to the best single junction solar cells.No understanding has ever been provided why this was the case. We have investigated the reasons for this behavior both at room temperature and at cryogenic temperatures ( all the way down to 170 K).. We have used a simple model to explain our results and have shown that the reason for not having higher conversion efficiency in intermediate band solar cells is related to the fact that the one-sun intensity is much lower (by several orders of magnitude)  than the satration intensity of the 2 transitions involved in the extra pathways for absorbing lower and higher energy photons. We have used the z-scan technique for extracting the saturation power for the intermediate band. As a consequence of our investigation, the intermediate band concept does not provide an enhancement of the conversion efficiency of single-junction solar cells. We have demonstrated that this is also true even when the single junction solar cell is operated at cryogenic temperatures, where the one-sun intensity is lower but still much larger that the reduced saturation intensity at lower temperatures..We expect this result to hold even for lower temperatures, all the way donw to liquid helium temperatures.This is an important result since there has been, and this continues to generate, multiple proposals for observing and demonstrating the intermediate band concept. In the future, research and development money can be better spent by looking at more promissing approaches to high conversion efficiency solar cells.
